titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Heard Mr: Howard of Canton, who dined with us. I wrote a letter to my wife— Finished reading Cowper’s translation of the Odyssey.

2. Warm weather is again making its appearance— I finished the 5th: and began upon the 6th: volume of the U.S. Laws— Mr: Fitch, and Mr: Allen the Sheriff came out and dined here— Gunning towards evening.

3. My brother went to Dedham, and from thence into Boston to dinner— I went with him as far as Milton Bridge— But overtaking Captain Beale, who was going into Boston alone, he gave me a seat with him.— Called on Mr Hall, and sat half an hour with him— We had at 12 a meeting of the Directors of Neponset Bridge. Pass’d a couple of votes and agreed to hold our next monthly meeting at the Bridge at 4. P.M.— I called on Coll: Bradford with an advertisement for the sale of My House in Half-Court Square next Tuesday.— Dined at Mr: Gardner’s— Mr: Jackson and Mr: Hall were there— My brother came in from Dedham while we were at dinner— In the afternoon we called at Mr: Foster’s, and saw Mr: Shaw who is very anxious to go out to Quincy— After missing my brother several times, I found him at last again at Mr: Foster’s, and we returned between 8 and 9 to Quincy— Whitcomb moved this day from my house.

4. Independence day— We were to have gone upon a fishing party, but could not procure a boat— Spent the day at home, and in the usual occupations, not forgetting it as my youngest child’s birth day— At the beginning of the Evening, my brother and myself bathed at the wharf— Mrs: Foster came over from Weymouth.

5. Weather very warm— Had a severe thunder shower this afternoon— In the morning I went with Captain Beale, and examined the Peach trees in his Garden— Found several of them infested with the worms; one of which I preserved, and gave him a peach into which he soon made his way— I bathed in the evening, alone at the wharf— Mrs: Cranch went into Boston, and brought out Mr: Shaw

6. Cool day— Return with some vigour to studies which in the excessive heat, I find myself conpell’d to remit in some degree— Read the Essay on Homer, at the head of Pope’s translation of the Iliad; and part of the Odyssey Book 5. in the Original— Millers making their appearance.

7. My brother Dined at Mr: D. Greenleaf’s.— Finished the first and began the Second Session of 7. Congress. Laws U.S.— In the afternoon, read the first Book of Pope’s Iliad— Compared it with Dryden’s, and with Cowper’s.— After a very warm day, we had in the Evening a continual glare of lightening; but not much Thunder, and very little rain.

8. Heard Mr: Whitney of Hingham— Mr: Fitch came out from Boston and spent the day here— Went to Mr: Quincy’s, and pass’d the evening there, with my brother.— Mr: Shaw was so unwell he could not leave his chamber—

9. A Justice’s Court held by my brother, and the company of Mr: Fitch, detained me great part of this morning, from my business— Yet I did not wholly neglect it— Summer is setting in with great fierceness— Mrs: Scott and Mrs: Beale, and Mr: Quincy were here this afternoon— Reading the 2d: Book of Pope’s Iliad— The Catalogue of Warriors— Compared the Geography with the map.

10. Mr: Fitch returned this morning to Boston. We had another day of excessive heat— I wrote in the forenoon as usual, and afternoon read Cowper’s Second Iliad— The extremity of the weather prevented me from much attention to the Greek— Mrs: D. Greenleaf was here this Evening.

11. I am this day 37 years of age— I finished the sixth and last Volume of the U.S. Laws— The last Session however, yet remains unpublished. Dr: Tufts and his lady were here this afternoon; and at dinner. Mr: Black, and B. Adams called in the Evening— I attempted to draw a meridian line; but was not successful.— Read the 3d: Book of the Iliad, in Pope’s and Cowper’s translations.

12. I went into Boston alone this morning— Found on my arrival that my house was not sold yesterday— Which was not unexpected to me— I paid my assessment at the New England Insurance Company Office, and received the Certificate of my Shares— Went for my trunks which have arrived from Washington, and on various other affairs, which employed me assiduously the whole day— Dined at Mr: Smith’s; and returned to Quincy in the Evening— Received a letter from my wife.

13. I propose to indulge myself with some days of leisure, or of attention to various and miscellaneous objects. This day, I partly arranged my accounts but did not complete them— Received a letter from Mr: J. Gardner— Wrote to my wife.— Mrs: Black was here this evening— Mr: & Mrs: Foster, from Boston.

14. Spent the forenoon in a shooting party with my brother— The game was plenty, and we brought in three dozen birds, between us— He dined at Mr: Barrett’s— Mr: T. Greenleaf was here this afternoon— My brother received this evening a letter from W. H. Sumner— This was a day of almost total intermission from serious occupations, reading or writing— I wish it may not the example of a long succession of them. But I find toil, mental or bodily, has become so wearisome, that there is danger I shall slink from it, for a time too much prolonged.

15. Heard Mr: Whitney this forenoon— But after dinner was detained at home by the rain— Made up my Accounts to the close of June— Read the 4th: Iliad in Pope’s translation— Captain Beale was here this Evening.

16. Copying the S.C.U.S. opinion in the case of Church and Hubbart to send to Mr: M’Cormick;—walk’d up to my farm this forenoon— Found almost all the apple-trees and peach-trees I had planted there in the Spring, alive and thrifty.— My Aunt Smith passed the day here.— This afternoon I read Mr: Peck’s description and history of the Slug-worm— And I pluck’d several upon the leaves of the Pear-trees in the garden to repeat some of his observations.
17. Bathed at the wharf below Mr: Black’s this morning. I was not very well— Finished the arrangement of my Accounts; and wrote a letter to Mr: Tracy.

18. Went to Boston with my brother— Called upon Mr: Dexter, and left Mrs: Hall’s papers with him; for his opinion, whether there is any legal remedy of which she can avail herself— Transacted that part of my business which I could accomplish, and left the rest unfinished. We went out to Roxbury and dined with Mr: W. H. Sumner, and a party of about 30 gentlemen; among whom was Mr: J. Rutledge, who arrived here last evening.— We returned this Evening to Quincy.

19. I had luckily declined an invitation from the Board of Health to go with them this day on their annual party to Rainsford’s Islands— The morning was fair but before noon the weather became foul and so continued the remainder of the day. I spent it very indolently.— My Mother took Susan over to Milton.

20. Dined with Mr: T. Amory at Roxbury. Mr and Mrs: Dexter; Mr: & Mrs: Payne, 2 Miss Payne’s, Miss Gray, Mr: Jonathan Amory and his wife, Mr: Taylor, and Mr: Hall were of the Company— I miss’d my way both in going and returning home.
21. The Gentlemen of the Club dined here, with my brother.— I spent part of the forenoon shooting. Wrote very little and read nothing this day.
22. Heard Mr: Williams of Weymouth— In the afternoon the principal part of the family went to Church, and heard Mr: Gardner.— Wrote to Mrs: A.
23. Company this afternoon at tea— Mr: Quincy and his family— Mr: & Mrs: Black &c. I rambled with my brother over the fields with our guns.— Wasted the day.
24. My mother and brother went to Milton this afternoon—to Mr: Boies’s— I was writing great part of the day; on a series of papers I have commenced— In the evening I went up to Mr: Cranch’s.

25. Young Dr: Danforth, and Mr: Sumner came out this morning from Boston, to breakfast— My brother and Mr: Shaw went with them to the Blue-hills to spend the day— Mr: Tudor came from town, and dined here— Mrs: Turner, Mrs: Bass and Mrs: Bordman were here also— Mrs: Black at tea— I was employed in writing; and stroll’d round the fields towards Evening.
26. Engaged the greatest part of the day in Writing— My Mother, brother and Mr: Shaw, were out this afternoon— At the Miss Edes’s— Mr: H. G. Otis delivered in Boston his Eulogy upon Genl: Hamilton.
27. My Mother and Brother went into Boston this morning, and return’d at Night— Mr: and Mrs: King and Mr: Benson were here this forenoon— I received two letters from my wife this Evening.

28. Wrote to Mrs: Adams this morning. Went into Boston with Mr: Shaw— Attended at the Office with Ripley’s Commissioners on the Meeting which was assigned— But neither of the Assignees attended and the business could not be done.— We adjourned to this day fortnight. 11. O’Clock— I called on Mr: Dexter, on Mrs: Hall’s business— Dined with Mr: S. A. Otis— Called on Mr: J. Gardner this afternoon— We return’d to Quincy early this evening— My Mother unwell.
29. Heard Mr: Whitney— On Anger— In the Evening I went down to Mr: Quincy’s— Saw his Apple-tree hedge. I read a little this day; but wrote nothing— Weather very warm.

30. Bathed at Mr: Black’s wharf, between 5 and 6 o’clock this morning, with my brother— Mr: Teal of Medford was here— Heat of the day excessive— I read Pope and Cowper’s translations of the 6th: Iliad— Containing the beautiful episode of Hector and Andromache.

31. Dined at Dr: Tufts’s at Weymouth— My Mother being unwell, and Louisa did not go. Mr: & Mrs: Tufts, Mr: and Mrs: Norton, a Mrs: Nicholls and Miss Marston were there— We had a very severe thunder shower while there, which returned repeatedly— Came home early— Bathed with my brother this morning.

Day— Since I finished the Analysis of the U.S. Laws, my time has been wasted very much in indolence. I am writing a series of papers, of which it is doubtful whether I shall ever make any use; and I occasionally read a book of Pope and Cowper’s translations of the Iliad— The general arrangement of my time is as the last Month.
